Men Also Do Laundry: Multi-Attribute Bias Amplification

An interpretable metric for measuring bias amplification from multiple attributes

Jun. 30, 2023

Dora Zhao

Sony AI, New York

Jerone Andrews

Sony AI, Tokyo

Alice Xiang

Sony AI, New York

  Paper   Code   Video

BibTeX


    @inproceedings{zhao2023men,
        title={Men Also Do Laundry: Multi-Attribute Bias Amplification},
        author={Zhao, Dora and Andrews, Jerone TA and Xiang, Alice},
        booktitle={International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML)},
        year={2023}
    }

Introduction

As computer vision systems become more widely deployed, there is increasing concern from both the research community and the public that these systems are not only reproducing but amplifying harmful social biases. The phenomenon of bias amplification, which is the focus of this work, refers to models amplifying inherent training set biases at test time[1].

Existing metrics[1, 2] measure bias amplification with respect to single annotated attributes (e.g., computer\texttt{computer}computer). However, large-scale visual datasets often have multiple annotated attributes per image. For example, in COCO[3] , 78.8% of the training set of images are associated with more than a single attribute (i.e., object).

For example, in imSitu[4], individually the verb unloading\texttt{unloading}unloading and location indoors\texttt{indoors}indoors are skewed male\texttt{male}male. However, when considering {unloading,indoors}\{\texttt{unloading}, \texttt{indoors}\}{unloading,indoors} in conjunction, the dataset is actually skewed female\texttt{female}female. Significantly, men tend to be pictured unloading packages outdoors whereas women are pictured unloading laundry or dishes indoors.

Key Takeaways

1. Models can leverage correlations between a demographic group and multiple attributes simultaneously, suggesting that current single-attribute metrics underreport the amount of bias being amplified.

2. We validate our proposed metric through an analysis of gender bias amplification on the COCO[3], imSitu[4], and CelebA [5] datasets. On average, bias amplification from multiple attributes is greater than that from single attributes.

3. We benchmark proposed bias mitigation methods[6, 1, 7, 8] using our metric and existing bias amplification metrics. Single-attribute bias mitigation methods can inadvertently increase multi-attribute bias.

Background

In their foundational work, Zhao et al.[1] propose a metric for bias amplification that measures the difference in object co-occurrences from the training to predicted distribution. Building on this work, Wang and Russakovsky[2] proposed the metric directional bias amplifcation to disentangle bias arising from the attribute versus group prediction. An alternative line of work has focused on using leakage[6, 9]—the change in a classifier's ability to predict group membership from the training data to predictions. Our work extends co-occurrence-based metrics[1, 2].

Multi-Attribute Bias Amplification Metrics

We denote by G={g1,…,gt}\mathcal{G}=\{g_1, \dots, g_t\}G={g1​,…,gt​} and A={a1,…,an}{\mathcal{A}=\{a_1,\dots,a_n\}}A={a1​,…,an​} a set of ttt group membership labels and a set of nnn attributes, respectively. Here gi∈Gg_i \in \mathcal{G}gi​∈G denotes group membership and ai∈A{a_i\in\mathcal{A}}ai​∈A denotes the absence (i.e., ai=0{a_i=0}ai​=0) or presence (i.e., ai=1{a_i=1}ai​=1) of attribute iii in xxx.

Let M={m1,…,mℓ}{\mathcal{M}=\{m_1,\dots,m_{\ell}\}}M={m1​,…,mℓ​} denote a set of ℓ\ellℓ sets, containing all possible combinations of attributes, where mim_imi​ is a set of attributes and ∣mi∣∈{1,…,n}\lvert m_i \rvert \in \{1,\dots, n\}∣mi​∣∈{1,…,n}.For example, if A={bicycle,car,motorcycle},\mathcal{A}=\{\texttt{bicycle}, \texttt{car}, \texttt{motorcycle}\},A={bicycle,car,motorcycle}, thenM={{bicycle},{car},{motorcycle},{bicycle,car},{bicycle,motorcycle},{car,motorcycle},{bicycle,car,motorcycle}}. \begin{aligned} \mathcal{M} = \{ & \{\texttt{bicycle}\}, \{\texttt{car}\}, \{\texttt{motorcycle}\},\\ & \{\texttt{bicycle}, \texttt{car}\}, \{\texttt{bicycle}, \texttt{motorcycle}\}, \{\texttt{car}, \texttt{motorcycle}\},\\ & \{\texttt{bicycle}, \texttt{car}, \texttt{motorcycle}\} \}. \end{aligned} M={​{bicycle},{car},{motorcycle},{bicycle,car},{bicycle,motorcycle},{car,motorcycle},{bicycle,car,motorcycle}}.​. Note m∈Mm\in\mathcal{M}m∈M if and only if co-occur(m,g)≥1\text{co-occur}(m, g) \geq 1co-occur(m,g)≥1 in both the ground-truth training set and test set.

We extend Zhao et al.'s[1] bias score to a multi-attribute setting such that the bias score of a set of attributes m∈Mm\in\mathcal{M}m∈M w.r.t. group g∈Gg\in\mathcal{G}g∈G is defined as: biastrain(m,g)=co-occur(m,g)∑g′∈Gco-occur(m,g′),\text{bias}_{\text{train}}(m, g) = \dfrac{\text{co-occur}(m, g)}{\displaystyle\sum_{g^\prime \in \mathcal{G}} \text{co-occur}(m, g^\prime)},biastrain​(m,g)=g′∈G∑​co-occur(m,g′)co-occur(m,g)​, where co-occur(m,g)\text{co-occur}(m, g)co-occur(m,g) denotes the number of times mmm and ggg co-occur in the training set.

Definition: Undirected Multi-Attribute Bias Amplification

We define our undirected multi-attribute bias amplification metric as: Our proposed metric extends Zhao et al.'s[1] single-attribute undirected bias amplification metric such that bias amplification from multiple attributes is measured. MultiMALS=X,variance(Δgm)\text{Multi}_\text{MALS} = X, \text{variance}(\Delta_{gm})MultiMALS​=X,variance(Δgm​) where X=1∣M∣∑g∈G∑m∈M∣Δgm∣ X = \frac{1}{\lvert \mathcal{M} \rvert}\sum_{g\in \mathcal{G} } \sum_{m\in \mathcal{M}} \left\lvert\Delta_{gm}\right\rvert X=∣M∣1​g∈G∑​m∈M∑​∣Δgm​∣ and Δgm=1[biastrain(m,g)>∣G∣−1]⋅(biastest(m,g)−biastrain(m,g)). \begin{aligned} \Delta_{gm} &= \mathbb{1}\left[ \text{bias}_{\text{train}}(m, g) > \lvert \mathcal{G}\rvert^{-1} \right] \cdot \\ &\left( \text{bias}_{\text{test}}(m, g) - \text{bias}_{\text{train}}(m, g)\right). \end{aligned} Δgm​​=1[biastrain​(m,g)>∣G∣−1]⋅(biastest​(m,g)−biastrain​(m,g)).​ Here biaspred(m,g)\text{bias}_{\text{pred}}(m, g)biaspred​(m,g) denotes the bias score using the test set predictions of mmm and ggg. MultiMALS\text{Multi}_\text{MALS}MultiMALS​ measures both the mean and variance over the change in bias score from the training set ground truths to test set predictions.

Definition: Directional Multi-Attribute Bias Amplification

Let m^\hat{m}m^ and g^\hat{g}g^​ denote a model's prediction for attribute group, mmm, and group membership, ggg, respectively. We define our directional multi-attribute bias amplification metric that takes into account the direction of bias as: Our proposed metric extends Wang and Russakovsky's[2] single-attribute directional bias amplification metric such that bias amplification from multiple attributes is measured. Multi→=X,variance(Δmg) \text{Multi}_{\rightarrow} = X, \text{variance}(\Delta_{mg}) Multi→​=X,variance(Δmg​) where X=1∣G∣∣M∣∑g∈G∑m∈Mygm∣Δgm∣+(1−ygm)∣−Δgm∣, \begin{aligned} X &=\frac{1}{\lvert \mathcal{G} \rvert \lvert \mathcal{M} \rvert} \sum_{g\in \mathcal{G}}\sum_{m\in \mathcal{M}} y_{gm}\left\lvert\Delta_{gm}\right\rvert+(1-y_{gm})\left\lvert-\Delta_{gm}\right\rvert, \end{aligned} X​=∣G∣∣M∣1​g∈G∑​m∈M∑​ygm​∣Δgm​∣+(1−ygm​)∣−Δgm​∣,​ ygm=1[Ptrain(g=1,m=1)>Ptrain(g=1)Ptrain(m=1)], \begin{aligned} y_{gm}=\mathbb{1} [ &P_{\text{train}}(g=1, m=1) \\ &> P_{\text{train}}(g=1) P_{\text{train}}(m=1)], \end{aligned} ygm​=1[​Ptrain​(g=1,m=1)>Ptrain​(g=1)Ptrain​(m=1)],​ and Δgm={Ptest(m^=1∣g=1)−Ptrain(m=1∣g=1)if measuring G→MPtest(g^=1∣m=1)−Ptrain(g=1∣m=1)if measuring M→G \begin{aligned} \Delta_{gm} &= \begin{cases} P_{\text{test}}(\hat{m}=1 \vert g=1) - P_{\text{train}}(m=1 \vert g=1) \\ \text{if measuring }G\rightarrow M\\ P_{\text{test}}(\hat{g}=1 \vert m=1) - P_{\text{train}}(g=1 \vert m=1) \\ \text{if measuring }M\rightarrow G \end{cases} \end{aligned} Δgm​​=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​Ptest​(m^=1∣g=1)−Ptrain​(m=1∣g=1)if measuring G→MPtest​(g^​=1∣m=1)−Ptrain​(g=1∣m=1)if measuring M→G​​ Unlike MultiMALS\text{Multi}_\text{MALS}MultiMALS​, Multi→\text{Multi}_{\rightarrow}Multi→​ captures both positive and negative correlations, i.e., Multi→\text{Multi}_{\rightarrow}Multi→​ iterates over all g∈Gg\in\mathcal{G}g∈G regardless of whether biastrain(m,g)>∣G∣−1\text{bias}_{\text{train}}(m, g) > \lvert \mathcal{G}\rvert^{-1}biastrain​(m,g)>∣G∣−1. Moreover, Multi→\text{Multi}_{\rightarrow}Multi→​ takes into account the base rates for group membership and disentangles bias amplification arising from the group influencing the attribute(s) prediction (MultiG→M\text{Multi}_{G \rightarrow M}MultiG→M​), as well as bias amplification from the attribute(s) influencing the group prediction (MultiM→G\text{Multi}_{M \rightarrow G}MultiM→G​).

Comparison with Existing Metrics

Our proposed multi-attribute metric has the following advantages over existing single-attribute co-occurence-based metrics:

Advantage 1: Our metric accounts for co-occurrences with multiple attributes. If a model, for example, learns the combination of a1a_1a1​ and a2a_2a2​, i.e., m={a1,a2}∈Mm=\{a_1, a_2\}\in\mathcal{M}m={a1​,a2​}∈M, are correlated with g∈Gg\in\mathcal{G}g∈G, it can exploit this correlation, potentially leading to bias amplification. By iterating over all m∈Mm \in \mathcal{M}m∈M, our proposed metric accounts for amplification from single and multiple attributes. Thus, capturing sets of attributes exhibiting amplification, which are not accounted for by existing metrics.

Advantage 2: Negative and positive values do not cancel each other out. Existing metrics calculate bias amplification by aggregating over the difference in bias scores for each attribute individually. Suppose there is a dataset with two annotated attributes a1a_1a1​ and a2a_2a2​. It is possible that Δga1≈−Δga2{\Delta_{ga_1} \approx -\Delta_{ga_2}}Δga1​​≈−Δga2​​. Since our metrics use absolute values, we ensure that positive and negative bias amplifications per attribute do not cancel each other out.

Advantage 3: Our metric is more interpretable. There is a lack of intuition as to what an “ideal” amplification value is. One interpretation is that smaller values are more desirable. This becomes less clear when values are negative. First, there often exists a trade-off between performance and smaller bias amplification values. Second, high magnitude negative bias amplification may lead to erasure of certain groups. For example, in imSitu, the biastrain({typing},F)=0.52\text{bias}_{\text{train}}(\{\texttt{typing}\}, \texttt{F}) = \textsf{0.52}biastrain​({typing},F)=0.52. Negative bias amplification signifies the model underpredicts ({typing},F)(\{\texttt{typing}\}, \texttt{F})({typing},F), which could reinforce negative gender stereotypes[1]. Instead, we may want to minimize the distance between the bias amplification value and zero. This interpretation offers the advantage that large negative values are also not desirable. However, a potential dilemma occurs when interpreting two values with the same magnitude but opposite signs, which is a value-laden decision and depends on the system's context.

Our proposed metric is easy to interpret. Since we use absolute differences, the ideal value is unambiguously zero. Further, reporting variance provides intuition about whether amplification is uniform across all attributes or if particular attributes are more amplified.

  4. M. Yatskar, L. Zettlemoyer, and A. Farhadi, “Situation recognition: Visual semantic role labeling for image understanding,” in IEEE/ CVF Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR), 2016.

  8. S. Agarwal, S. Muku, S. Anand, and C. Arora, “Does Data Repair Lead to Fair Models? Curating Contextually Fair Data To Reduce Model Bias,” in IEEE/CVF Winter Conference on Applications of Computer Vision (WACV), 2022.
